advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, APRIL 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, April 1982<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The new ASC8000-6 single board computer is packed with ultra-high technology: Z80 double density computer, up to 2048Kb of high speed RAM, Floppy-disk and Winchester Hard Disk controllers, DMA, up to 6 serial / 2 parallel I/O, optional 32 bit floating point processor... All on one board, fully socketed, fully documented, reliable and maintainable...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.computermuseum.it</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the 16K static RAM expansion is more expensive than the computer itself.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SALES CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this catalog, NEWMAN COMPUTER EXCHANGE from Ann Arbor sold various Interact packages, from $44.95 for an incomplete and inoperative 8K model, to $299.95 for a 16K system along with 30 software cassettes and a complete documentation including the service manuals set. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>I bellissimi...<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (OCTOBER, 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Particuliar sign : painter and musician''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MONROE ADVERT, FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Last sales in the UK. At the same time, a Commodore VIC-20 cost £139 and a Commodore 64 cost $229</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARGENTINIAN ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.speccy.org/czarg/" target="_blank">CZARG</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> £99 IN JANUARY 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST VICTOR ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>with the original Victor design.<br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">The Victor 9000. It's a desktop system computer designed to be a "cut above" the rest...</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.guiguy.com/Schiff/" target="_blank">www.guiguy.com/Schiff/</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first sentence of this advert is:<br> <i>The new Commodore 64 is the most powerful personal computer available to the businessman.</i><br> Which wasn't totally true, even totally false.<br><br> The picture is also totally unrealistic. Each detail sounds false.<br> The C64 never was a business system, but a perfect home computer. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> USA RADIO SHACK CATALOG (1991)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR TECHNOLOGIES CREATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The conbination of Victor Business Products and Sirius Systems Technology Inc. creates a new company designed to meet the most demanding needs of the modern business office...<br> ... The result is Victor Technologies Inc., a company idally suited to dramatically impact today's international computer marketplace.<br><br> The Chairman of the board of the new Victor Technologies in Fred Sullivan, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Kiddle, Inc., a diversified $3 billion company. The financial support of this giant conglomerate will help focus Victor's goal of becoming one of the three leading computer companies in the world.<br> President and Chief Executive Officer of the new company is Chuck Peddle. Acknowledged as the "father" of the personal computer concept, Peddle introduced this useful and very affordable third generation micro-computer in the European market with startling results..</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> HEATH 19 TERMINAL (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>$595 was the price in kit form, F.O.B. Benton Harbor...<br> The assembled version, called Zenith Z-19, costed $895. An expensive price, not compatible with a home computer budget. </blockquote>

computer.description:
The Kaypro 2x was one of the last models Kaypro produced. Size and appearence were the same as the first Kaypro II, but Internal hardware was inspired by the Kaypro 10.
It came with a 4 MHz Z80A processor, dual slimline 400 KB floppy drives, a built-in 300 baud modem, two serial ports and a full set of Micropro software (WordStar, CalcStar, DataStar)
It is said that Arthur C. Clarke worked in the movie version of "2010: Odyssey Two", a sequel of "2001", using a Kaypro 2x and its built-in modem for transfering texts from Sri Lanka, where he lived, to Los Angeles. _______________________
computer.keyboard: Detachable, 72 key typewriter style keyboard with 18 programmable keys.
computer.media: 2 x 5.25'' DS/DD 400 KB half-size floppy drives
computer.name: Kaypro 2x
computer.ports: 2 RS232c serial ports, 1 Centronics-type parallel port, keyboard, built-in 300-baud modem

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> LARGER VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that some Kaypro 2X models had a "2X" label on the front panel, between the two floppy drives. This version only have a "X" sticker on the back panel. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUNNING SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Kaypro 2x is running ProfitPlan, a spreadsheet program from Chang Laboratories.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>The keyboard, made by Keytronic, was build sturdy.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Power plug, switch and fuse<br> <b>(2)</b> Reset button<br> <b>(3)</b> The case was designed to take a fan but most of the Kaypro models didn't need it<br> <b>(4)</b> Modem RJ11 plug<br> <b>(5)</b> Parallel printer connector<br> <b>(6)</b> The Kaypro 2x sticker<br> <b>(7)</b> Serial port for data I/O<br> <b>(8)</b> Second serial port for serial printer<br> <b>(9)</b> Keyboard RJ11 plug<br> <b>(10)</b> Brightness control knob<br><p class="petitgris">Special thanks to <b>Thomas J. Casey</b> who donates us this computer</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The main board is taken off. One can see the video circuitry and the switching power supply unit.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> 8 x Mostek 4564 chips hold the 64 KB of RAM<br> <b>(2)</b> Memory controller chip labelled Kaypro<br> <b>(3)</b> BIOS ROM chips<br> <b>(4)</b> Mostek Z80A processor<br> <b>(5)</b> Characters generator ROM<br> <b>(6)</b> MOS display controller<br> <b>(7)</b> MOS serial I/O controllers<br> <b>(8)</b> Siemens floppy drives controller<br> <b>(9)</b> Several empty sockets are probably used for an optional hard disk controller<br> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLOPPY DRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Slimline floppy drives came from an U.S. company called High Tech Peripherals, but they were probably made in Japan.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARTHUR C. CLARKE </strong></font><br><blockquote>Arthur C. Clarke working with his Kaypro computer.</blockquote>
